turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Look -- if you don't like the way I'm handling this job --

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Kill it, Duke. It's got us all spinning.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Don't worry. We'll take care of it.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Take some men and get the antenna going. Let's see if we can catch the BBC.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You're wasting your time, Duke.  Outside, everybody! Let's get it over with.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Wait a second, Hoffy. Schulz says he's our best friend. Maybe he can give us a little hint.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Answer the question. How do you rate all those privileges?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Cut the horseplay, Harry. What's the matter with you guys?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: And don't blame me if you all wind up in the cooler.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: It's not Schulz. It's that stoolie. Whoever he is, he's sure batting a thousand.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: The guy I want to talk to is Sefton. Where's Sefton?  You haven't seen Sefton, have you?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: I want everybody out of here. We'll need a lot of commotion on the compound.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: I don't know what your scheme is, but it sounds crazy.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Maybe it's crazy, but it's better than having Dunbar dead.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Just as you say, Hoffy. But wouldn't it be smarter if I went out and kept Schulz tied up?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: What about Schulz?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: We'll take care of Schulz.  Come on.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: No volunteers, Price. I said we're all in on it.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: You have elected me Security. The way things have been going in this Barracks, I guess I've done a poor job and I want to make up for it. Is that asking too much?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: We've all done a poor job of it.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: I still say this is my tag. Any objections, Hoffy?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Any objections, men?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: What do you say, Hoffy. We'll hit the air raid trenches and cut out in back of Barracks nine.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You'd better cut out in back of the south latrine.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Why the south latrine?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Because that's where he is. In the water tank.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Los, los. Dummkopf!

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Lay off, Schulz. He's got a sickness. He's krank.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Sometimes I think he is fooling us with that crazy business.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Yeah? How would you like to see the guts of nine pals splattered all over your plane?  C'mon Joey -- don't be afraid.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: We know! We got them last year. Five minutes after the Geneva Man was gone, the blankets were gone.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: One more thing, gentlemen. The Kommandant told me to pick up the radio.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: What radio?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: The one you are hiding in the barrack, don't you know? The one your friend without the leg is smuggling all over the compound.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: You must get out. For your own good, you must get out.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Come on, everybody!  Let's go!

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Stay out of it, Sefton.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Just one question. Did you calculate the risk?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Anybody call?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Go on, Sefton -- butt out!

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: If I were you, Sefton, I'd eat that egg some place else. Like for instance under the barrack.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: A little weak today.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: If you can't get the BBC, how about getting Guy Lombardo?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Are we boring you?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: What's the big idea, Sefton? Take that telescope out of here.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Says who?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Says me.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You take it out. Only you're going to have a riot on your hands.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Every time the men get Red Cross packages you have to think up an angle to rob them.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Lay off, Sefton.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: With your mother's pull, how come you're not a chicken colonel by now?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Lay off, I said -- if you don't want your head handed to you.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: What's the matter, boys? Is my slip showing?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: I'll say it is. You spilled a little borscht on it.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Borscht?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: What happened, Cookie? Who did it?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: We did it.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: There better not be anything missing. This is private property.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: What's it add up to you, Sefton?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: It adds up that you got yourselves the wrong guy. Because I'm telling you. The Krauts wouldn't plant two stoolies in one barrack. And whatever you do to me you're going to have to do all over again when you find the right guy.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You heard that, Sefton?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Sure I heard it. I still got one good ear.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You'll stay in this barracks and not a peep out of you.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Okay, then. Put a guard on me. I want you to put a guard on me. Because if anything goes wrong out there, this time you won't have a patsy. Right?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: So who stays with me? Maybe Joey? No -- not Joey. Wouldn't you feel safer with Security on the job?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Okay, Price. You stay.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Two packs of cigarettes say Dunbar never gets out of the compound.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You starting that again?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Anybody cover?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Hurry up on that trap.  What are you trying to do, Sefton? Gum up the works?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: That's right. Or would you rather see Dunbar lying out there in the mud tomorrow morning like Manfredi and Johnson?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Look, Sefton, I had my hands full so they wouldn't tear you apart --

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I called it the last time, didn't I?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: How do they know?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You told them, Hoffy.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Who did?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You did!

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You off your rocker?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Uh-huh. Fell right on my head.  Sprechen sie deutsch?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: He's a Nazi, Price is. For all I know, his name is Preismaier or Preissinger. Sure, he lived in Cleveland, but when the war broke out he came back to the Fatherland like a good little Bundist. He spoke our lingo so they put him through spy school, gave him phony dogtags --

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: What are we going to do with him?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Don't you know? Because I got my own ideas.  Let's have that civilian stuff.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: You taking Dunbar?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You betcha. There ought to be some reward money from Mama. Say ten thousand bucks worth.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I told you boys I'm no escape artist, but for the first time, I like the odds. Because now I got me a decoy.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: What's the decoy?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Price. When I go I want you to give me five minutes. Exactly five minutes to get Dunbar out of that water tank. Then you throw Price out into the compound, nice and loud. He'll draw every light from every goon tower. It's our only chance to cut through. What do you say, Barracks' Chief?

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Shoot!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You could use a new one yourself.

turns.speaker: HOFFY
turns.text: Let's synchronize the watches. Eleven forty-two, sharp.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: MARKO
turns.text: Today's Camp News!  Father Murray announces that due to local regulations the Christmas midnight Mass will be held at seven in the morning!

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: You can tell Father Murray to --

turns.speaker: MARKO
turns.text: At ease! He also says, quote: All you sack rats better show up for the services and no bull from anybody. Unquote. At ease! Monday afternoon a sailboat race will be held at the cesspool. See Oscar Rudolph of Barrack 7 if you want to enter a yacht. Next: Jack Cushingham and Larry Blake will play Frank deNotta and Mike Cohen for the pinochle championship of the camp.

turns.speaker: MARKO
turns.text: Pirelli. Coleman. Agnew. Shapiro.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Nothing for Kuzawa?

turns.speaker: MARKO
turns.text: Shapiro. Shapiro.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Just what makes you so popular?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MARKO
turns.text: Give this to Joey, will you?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Now you've done it. You've given me nervous indigestion.  Anything else bothering you, boys?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Just one little thing. How come you were so sure Manfredi and Johnson wouldn't get out of the forest?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I wasn't so sure. I just liked the odds.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: And what's that crack supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: They're lying dead in the mud out there and I'm trying to find out how come.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I'll tell you how come.  The Barrack Chief gave them the green light. And you, our Security Officer, said it'd be safe. That's how come.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: When the Krauts find that gadget they'll throw us all in the boob.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: They know about that gadget. I'd worry more about the radio.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: So was the radio private property. So was Manfredi and Johnson.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: What about the radio?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Or how about a game of pinochle? No, you're not a pinochle man. You're a chess player.  I haven't played since I was a kid. Let's see --  -- a pawn moves this way, doesn't it? And a bishop this way? And the queen -- every which way, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Suppose you just sit down and keep your mouth shut.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I went to school with a guy named Price. But that was in Boston. You're from Cleveland, aren't you.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Yes, I'm from Cleveland.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I thought that's what you said. You're from Cleveland. And you were with the Thirty-sixth Bomb Group?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Thirty-fifth.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Three hundred and sixty-fifth Bomb Squadron? Out of Chelveston?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Are you questioning me?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Just getting acquainted. Trying to make one friend in this barracks.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Don't bother, Sefton. I don't like you. I never did and I never will.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: A lot of people say that and the first thing you know is they get married and live happily ever after.  I wonder what they're trying to pull out there?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Ach so!

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Amazing, what you can do with five thousand ping-pong balls, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Stop that, will you!  Those idiots! So they sprang Dunbar! So what good is it? He's still in the compound, isn't he? How long can he last? Where can they hide him?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Where. Up Joey's ocarina. Didn't you know?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Are we going to stand around here and listen to him until the Germans find out where Dunbar is?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: The Germans know where Dunbar is.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: No. I don't sprechen sie deutsch.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Maybe just one word? Kaput? Because you're kaput, Price.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Will you get this guy out of my hair so I can go?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Go where? To the Kommandant's office and tell him where Dunbar is?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: I'll kill you for that!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Shut up!  Security Officer, eh? Screening everybody, only who screened you? Great American hero. From Cleveland, Ohio! Enlisted right after Pearl Harbor! When was Pearl Harbor, Price? Or, don't you know?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: December seventh, forty-one.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: What time?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Six o'clock. I was having dinner.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Six o'clock in Berlin. They were having lunch in Cleveland.  Am I boring you, boys?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: The one you took out of the corner of your bunk and put in this pocket.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Say, Schulz -- you guys had machine gun practice last night?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Ach, terrible! Such foolish boys. Such nice boys. I'd better not talk about it. It makes me sick to my stomach.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Let us see. We have now two empty bunks here.  Nummer einundsiebzig und Nummer dreiundsiebzig in Baracke vier.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Suppose you let those mattresses cool off a little -- just out of decency?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Ja, ja, gewiss! It is only that we are cramped for space with new prisoners every day.  Gentlemen! Outside! Please! Do you want me to have trouble with the Kommandant again!

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Which one of us is the informer?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: You are trying to say that an American would inform on other Americans?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Schulz, you're off your nut!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Give me the radio.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: We have no radio.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: All right, gentlemen, I will find it myself. Now let's see.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Nun? Was ist? Haben Sie's herausgefunden?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Ich weiss alles.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Wie hat er's gemacht?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: Ganz einfach... Streichhoelzer... und eine Zigarette...

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Good morning, Sefton.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Good morning, Schulz. And how's Mrs. Schulz? And all the little Schulzes?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Fine -- fine!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: No use, Schulz. You might as well come clean. Why don't you just tell 'em it's me. Because I'm really the illegitimate son of Hitler. And after the Germans win the war you'll make me the Gauleiter of Zinzinnati.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: You Americans! You are the craziest people! That's why I like you! I wish I could invite you all to my house for a nice German Christmas!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Du lieber Gott! How do you look? You had a fight?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: How would you like to give Frau Schulz a pair of silk stockings for Christmas?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: You should go and see the doctor. Maybe I can --  Silk stockings?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Here. Take them.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Wunderbar! Maybe they are too wunderbar for my wife. But there is a piano teacher in the village --

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: And how about three hundred cigarettes for yourself?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Three hundred cigarettes! What is it you want from me?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Who's the guy, Schulz?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: What guy?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: The one you work with. Who is he? How do you do it?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: I do not want those cigarettes.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Yes, you do!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: I'll make it five hundred!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: No! No!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You'd better talk, Schulz, because I'm going to find out with you or without you. Because I won't let go for a second. Because they'll have to kill me to stop me. So talk!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Talk what? I do not know anything!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: How many do you want? A thousand?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: What's the matter with you? You want to be killed?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Not particularly.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Hey, Schulz -- as long as you're going to move somebody in -- how about a couple of those Russian broads?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Russian women prisoners?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Just get us a couple with big Glockenspiels.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Ja! Ja! Droppen Sie dead!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Did I interrupt something, gentlemen?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Yeah. We were just passing out guns.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Always joking. Always making wisecrackers!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: This is me in Cincinnati.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Who's the other wrestler? The one with the mustache?

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: That is my wife.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Look at all that meat. Isn't she the bitter end!

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Give it back. You must not arouse yourselves.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: All right, gentlemen! We will now all go outside for a little gymnastic and take some shovels and undig the tunnel which you digged.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Why don't we just plug up that tunnel -- with the Kommandant on one end and you on the other.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: It is not me. It is the orders. I am your friend. I am your best friend here.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Gentlemen, tomorrow morning the Geneva Man is coming to inspect the camp whether we are living up to the International Convention. I am sure he will find we are treating you very well. You must not run around in your underwear. And take off the wash. The Kommandant wants all the barracks to be spic and also span.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: We'll put pink ribbons on the bedbugs.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: The Kommandant also sends you clean blankets. He wants every man to have a new, clean blanket.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: My grandmother's ear-muffs.

turns.speaker: SCHULTZ
turns.text: Look at them, Lieutenant. Everybody is a clown! How do you expect to win the war with an army of clowns?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: From a chicken, bug-wit.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: A chicken?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Is it all right if we smell it?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Just don't drool on it.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: That wouldn't be the cigarettes you took us for last night?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: What was I going to do with them? I only smoke cigars.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: You must have been some tail gunner!  Go ahead, Cookie.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Come on, let's get that mail. Anything for Stanislaus Kuzawa?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Have a nice time over there?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Oh! Somebody was peeking!

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: So you're stuck with me, eh?

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: Maybe those Russian dames would take him.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: You heard him.

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Okay, Herr Preismaier, let's have the mail box.

turns.speaker: STOSH
turns.text: You're not disposing of those Russian broads?

turns.speaker: SEFTON
turns.text: Tell you what to do. First, get yourself a hundred cigarettes for the Kraut guards. Then get yourself another face.

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: Toh-pak-cha=8A

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: HoS qorDu.

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: The Captain would make a much more valuable hostage.

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: We'll consider it a prisoner exchange.

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: It's working.

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: I thought he was the Chief Engineer.

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: He is.

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: Then when is he going to Engineering?

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: Where is he now?

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: I don't know. He bathed, now he is roaming the ship. He must be the only Engineer in Starfleet who does not go to Engineering!

turns.speaker: LURSA
turns.text: Target their Bridge.

turns.speaker: B'ETOR
turns.text: Full disruptors.

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Actually, Captain, your precise target area was thirty-five meters that way.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Thanks for pointing that out.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Tomorrow I want to make a tri-elliptical jump. That's where you jump out over Northern China and make three complete orbits before you start re-entry.

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Captain. Perhaps you have forgotten that tomorrow is the christening ceremony.

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Captain=8A

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I don't want to hear anymore about it. I'm not going, and that's final.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: But that wasn't so long ago. It couldn't have been more than...

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Twelve years, sir.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Yes, well, congratulations, Ensign. It wouldn't be the Enterprise without a Sulu at the helm.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: According to our information, the ribbon is a conflux of temporal energy which travels through our galaxy every 39.1 years

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: When is it expected back?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Data?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Sorry, Captain. The ribbon has already entered the galaxy. It will pass through this sector in approximately thirty-one hours.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Guinan said Soran was trying to get back to the ribbon. If that's true, then there must be some connection with the Amargosa star.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: The star's destruction has had numerous astro-physical effects within this sector. However, none of them appear to have a connection to the energy ribbon.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Give me a list of those effects. I want to know every single thing which has been altered or changed, no matter how insignificant.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: It will take a few moments for the computer to compile the information.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Data, are you all right?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: No, sir. I am finding it difficult to concentrate. I believe I am overwhelmed with feelings of remorse and regret concerning my actions on the observatory.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I wanted to save Geordi. I tried. But I experienced something I did not expect.  I believe it was fear.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Fear is a very difficult emotion to overcome. It's something we all have to learn to deal with.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: But I did not deal with it, sir. I let it prevent me from helping my friend.  Does that make me a coward?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: No. And what you must try to avoid is becoming consumed by another emotion which I believe you're beginning to experience: guilt.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Guilt. It is a most unpleasant feeling.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: According to our current information, the destruction of the Amargosa star has had the following effects in this sector: gamma emissions have increased by .05 percent, the starship Bozeman was forced to make a course correction, a research project on Gorik IV was halted due to increased neutrino particles, ambient magnetic fields have decreased by-

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Wait. The Bozeman,why did it change course?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: The destruction of the Amargosa star has altered the gravitational forces throughout the sector. Any ship passing through this region will have to make a minor course correction.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: This is its current position.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Can you project its course?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Courage is an emotion too, Data.  Now, can you project the course of the ribbon?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I believe so.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Now, you said the gravitational forces in this sector have been altered, could that also affect the course of the ribbon?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I believe so.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: He can't go to the ribbon, so he's trying to make the ribbon come to him.  Data, is it going to pass near any M-Class planets?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Yes, sir. There are two in the Veridian system.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: That's where he's going.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: It should be noted, sir, that the collapse of the Veridian star would produce a shock wave similar to the one we observed at Amargosa.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: And destroy every planet in the system.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Are any of them inhabited?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Veridian III is uninhabited, but Veridian IV supports a pre-industrial humanoid society.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Population?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Approximately two hundred thirty million.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: "Lifeforms tiny little lifeforms. Where are the lifeforms-"

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Commander.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Sorry, sir.  There is too much interference in the planet's ionosphere for an accurate reading.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Approximately forty-seven minutes, sir.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I have to find a way to get to Soran.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Is she still angry?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: No, but I'd stay out of Sickbay for a while if I were you. I still don't know why you dropped her in the water.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I was attempting to get in the spirit of things. I thought it would be humorous.
